(1 comment)
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 3590bd1dee5a0e56d4d282f0a1e3cf2c8804dfa1

Lots more details needed here around how you're propagating errors, and what the intended logic is.

How are return codes handled?
how are error messages handled?
What portions of the spec are we obeying here.

Thanks for your comments. 

Your other comments are all related to this. So I will just respond here

In this commit, the behavior is well explained/tested in unit test, I can add more words in commit message.

We do this in this commit:

1. if the finalResponse is already errored out, we return that error;
2. if finalResponse is ok, but the some intermediate response errored out, we set finalResponse to that error;

This means finalResponse only respects the first error.

> What portions of the spec are we obeying here.

I didn't find any clarification about error propagation on expand.

So, you wanna add combine all error messages of response? Is this behavior in the spec? I could see it can returns more useful errors and good for clients. Appending error messages is easy. But how to combine error code? Is there a spec to follow?

> This means finalResponse only respects the first error.

The last time this issue came up, that wasn't the conclusion, because we should be propogating all errors to the user.  Please take a look at the existing code, I think it can be reused as-is, and the behavior is already what we want I think.

> Is this behavior in the spec? 

Yes, and this is the behavior bmcweb uses elsewhere, that had a lot of discussion put into it including talking with DMTF many years ago.  If we're breaking that behavior, I'd like us to be clear WHY we're doing something different in expand compared to when we do async aggregation of errors.
The commit message has been updated.
Can we add more to the commit msg about "What portions of the spec are we obeying here." / "Is this behavior in the spec?"?

That's nothing in the Redfish spec clarified this errors propagating (I might miss things though). I implemented "the behavior bmcweb uses elsewhere".

Please see the above threads.

> That's nothing in the Redfish spec clarified this errors propagating

Really?  At the very least we can quote the portions of the spec that state where the "error" messages go, even if it' doesn't directly have an impact to expand.
I added links to "error" messages and documented why we have such behavior implemented.
Totally agree this is hard to test given we need to simulate bugs in the implementation;  I think your approach is the best we're going to be able to do at the moment.
nit, do we want to just inline this code?  placeResult is a 4 line function, and given that this is doing things like checking return codes, you'd think you'd want that check in the calling scope.
Separating it makes unit test much easier. So I prefer keeping it as is
ACK.  Seems reasonable.
I think we can rely ONLY on the error field existing, we don't need to check return codes here for anything more than adding.
Ack
Duplicated check?
No. here is subResponse, the above is finalResponse
You're right, I missed that.  ACK.

This doesn't function if there are multiple errors.  There's code in error_messages.cpp that handles this case already, we should just reuse that logic, as we already know it's "correct" to what we intend, and I think handles this with:

1. The first error gets propogated to the top level.
2. Subsequent errors convert the top level error to a "GeneralError" and append the errors to the list.

I think that's the same behavior we need here.
Yes, I used `addMessageToErrorJson` here.

> what if finalResponse is 500, and subResponse is 200?  The 500 will get overridden, right?

The current code is correct. It will return early before we override a wrong code. But current code doesn't add multiple errors.

> now, I'm not sure > is the right operator above, we might need an explicit list of "X error is greater than Y error".  For example, 401 might be higher than 404.

What's the relational? Report the worst code? Where can we get the explicit list of "X error is greater than Y error"? Do we accept max for now?

> > what if finalResponse is 500, and subResponse is 200?  The 500 will get overridden, right?
> 
> The current code is correct. It will return early before we override a wrong code. But current code doesn't add multiple errors.
> 
> > now, I'm not sure > is the right operator above, we might need an explicit list of "X error is greater than Y error".  For example, 401 might be higher than 404.
> 
> What's the relational? Report the worst code?

Yes.

> Where can we get the explicit list of "X error is greater than Y error"? 

We make it.  There's only a dozen or so error codes that we use in bmcweb, it should be pretty easy to rank them in a way that works.  The important ones are

500 is the highest priority
5XX after that
401 after that
4XX after that
the rest.

> Do we accept max for now?

I don't know what this question means.  What is "max"?

max refers to when there are error codes like 501 and 502, the combination result is 502.

I have implemented what you said.

I need jason to look at this.  I don't remember all the corner cases here.

@jmbills?
Should we just pass error as nlohmann::json::object_t, then we can avoid this check?

If we don't do this here, we have to do conversion outside, right?

Similar checks appears a lot in this source.
Resolved for now. Please reopen if you don't agree.

Just a note, if things are still under discussion, generally I try to leave them open and not resolved.  Resolving them with no changes made to the underlying code and outstanding questions being asked makes it much harder to track which items are still being discussed.

Keep in mind, it's not your job as a submitter to close ALL comments, only the ones where you made the change requested.  It's perfectly reasonable for a question asker to resolve the comment.

With that said, yeah, I think you're correct the way the code is written now.  ACK.

I don't think this handles all the cases.  An individual caller might:
1. Put the error code on the root of the object
2. Put the error code under the "errors" array.

I think we need to search first at the root, looking for GeneralError.  If GeneralError is set, we need to iterate the error array.  If the root error is something other than GeneralError, we need to append that directly.

What you have described are all handled.

Please take a look at the existing function addMessageToErrorJson.

If there's no error in root, root will get the message and code of the first message. Otherwise, root gets GeneralError and message is added to the exiting array. 


Resolved for now. Please reopen if you don't agree.

> If there's no error in root, root will get the message and code of the first message. 

Right, and that root error message needs propagated.  This code is only looking at the error key, because that's all that was passed in.

The code as I'm reading it:
looks for @Message.ExtendedInfo
tries to open @Message.ExtendedInfo as an array

Loops over each message.

In the case where the message is on the root, isn't the array empty?


Also, another thing we probably need to be doing here is filtering out the error message from the sub-request object, otherwise we're duplicating the error information in the tree, and putting "error" keys deep in the tree where they don't belong.

Oh, are you saying the error of subquery can be just be a single error object without "@Message.ExtendedInfo".

Done. Handled error as root.

> Also, another thing we probably need to be doing here is filtering out the error message from the sub-request object

this is already considered in this patch. See

```
subResponse.jsonValue.erase(errorIt)
```

This commit corrects the behavior, so that the final response gets all
error message of subqueries and the "highest priority" HTTP code. ?

Yes. I thought the commit is clear enough :)

Anything you wanna add?

> Anything you wanna add?

I think Gunnar was giving you the suggestion of what text to put there instead.  IMO, I agree, Gunnars wording is more clear.
Done

Can we walk through the commonly used return codes (at the very least the documented ones) and make this order explicit?


Also, I suspect we need some amount of handling for the caching return codes?

It doesn't have to be perfect order-wise, but lets make sure it's explicit.

> Also, I suspect we need some amount of handling for the caching return codes?

Which code? You mean https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_HTTP_status_codes#Caching_warning_codes? 

I saw that "Unlike the other status codes above, these are not sent as the response status in the HTTP protocol, but as part of the "Warning" HTTP header". Do we still to handle them?

> Can we walk through the commonly used return codes (at the very least the documented ones) and make this order explicit?

Yes, I have documented the explicit order in related code.

No, I mean: https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/DEVELOPING.md#error-handling

> Yes, I have documented the explicit order in related code.

you have documented an order for ranges of codes, but I'd like at least the common ones explicitly ordered before any of the ranges.



git grep -h -o boost::beast::http::status::\[a-z_]\* | sort | uniq                                                                                         
boost::beast::http::status::
boost::beast::http::status::accepted
boost::beast::http::status::bad_gateway
boost::beast::http::status::bad_request
boost::beast::http::status::conflict
boost::beast::http::status::continue_
boost::beast::http::status::created
boost::beast::http::status::forbidden
boost::beast::http::status::insufficient_storage
boost::beast::http::status::internal_server_error
boost::beast::http::status::method_not_allowed
boost::beast::http::status::no_content
boost::beast::http::status::not_acceptable
boost::beast::http::status::not_found
boost::beast::http::status::not_implemented
boost::beast::http::status::ok
boost::beast::http::status::precondition_failed
boost::beast::http::status::service_unavailable
boost::beast::http::status::temporary_redirect
boost::beast::http::status::unauthorized


Those are all the codes we use currently, and I think should be on a list that gets aggregated up.
Done. Added an explicit list
nit: use different variable name, final can also be used as keyword
Done
Thanks! Somehow I missed this comment.
I have one comment, that's arguably a nit.  I don't think we need to hold this up any longer.
Source should be const, right?  Should both be nlohmann::json::object_t?

> Source should be const, right?

No. Source is modified. Its errors will be removed once propagated to |target|.

>  Should both be nlohmann::json::object_t?

This requires changing existing codes. I can clean up this in the future.
Done
